messages.message:
I was showing our new user permissions to a customer we’re PoV’ing with (Vitality a UK insurer)

They said they liked it but were wondering why the reviewer has the ability to edit ground truth datasets?

For example if they hire an offshore person in India to only do the manual corrections in human review, they don’t necessarily want that person to be able to edit ground truths that could affect their measurement of solution performance.

I didn’t have an answer - wondering if you have one? cc @hannah @jack.robbins

Often times customers will want their human review teams to take on setting up these datasets, since they may have 100s of documents. Also, since human review teams ultimately will be the source of truth in production, many want the same individuals setting those ground truth values.

The development team could set the app version visibility to private though if they don't want these accessible to the reviewers (this has some drawbacks), or separate the ground truth datasets & accuracy tests into workspaces the reviewers can't access.
Got it thanks - what are the drawbacks of setting app version visibility to private? i think the latter seems reasonable cc @cyrille
Only the app author (a single user) & admins would be able to find the app on the Hub.
It's practically only feasible for super small teams, I agree the workspace-based approach is cleaner.
